articles.headline: Airfares Made Easy (or Easier)
articles.snippet: Farecast, an airfare search engine, predicts how much the price of an airline ticket will rise or fall over the coming days.
articles.abstract: Farecast, an airfare search engine, predicts how much the price of an airline ticket will rise or fall over the coming days.
articles.lead_paragraph: You squeeze into your seat in the airliner, buckle up and then, against your best judgment, you start asking your seat mates what they paid for their airfare.

articles.headline: Congo Nears Historic Election, Praying for Peace
articles.snippet: Congo's biggest challenge will be getting its competing groups to recognize and respect the election results.
articles.abstract: Congo's biggest challenge will be getting its competing groups to recognize and respect the election results.
articles.lead_paragraph: GOMA, Congo — The drawing the Rev. Israel Mulenda held in his hands was as succinct a précis as any of the nightmares this vast central African nation has lived for the past decade.

articles.headline: G.I.'s Investigated in Slayings of 4 and Rape in Iraq
articles.snippet: The investigation is the fourth into suspected killings of unarmed Iraqis by American soldiers announced by the military in June.
articles.abstract: The investigation is the fourth into suspected killings of unarmed Iraqis by American soldiers announced by the military in June.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 30 — The American military is investigating accusations that soldiers raped an Iraqi woman in her home and killed her and three family members, including a child, American officials said Friday.

articles.headline: Two Views of Terror Suspects: Die-Hards or Dupes
articles.snippet: Videotapes of the seven men arrested in Miami did not provide evidence that they had any ties to Al Qaeda.
articles.abstract: Videotapes of the seven men arrested in Miami did not provide evidence that they had any ties to Al Qaeda.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI, June 30  The seven men who were arrested here last week on terror charges were shown Friday on undercover videotapes solemnly reciting oaths of loyalty to Al Qaeda, repeating the words that an F.B.I. informant had given them to say.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Generic Drugs: The Window Has Loopholes
articles.snippet: A drug maker can license what has come to be called an "authorized generic" of its drug once its patent is broken.
articles.abstract: A drug maker can license what has come to be called an "authorized generic" of its drug once its patent is broken.
articles.lead_paragraph: A WEEK ago yesterday, Zocor's United States patent protection expired. Zocor, of course, is Merck's big cholesterol-lowering drug, which last year generated $4.4 billion for the company. As Alex Berenson pointed out in The New York Times, that makes Zocor "the largest-selling drug yet to be opened to generic competition."

articles.headline: G.M. Is Pressed to Form Alliance With Two Rivals
articles.snippet: Under a proposal by the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, Renault and Nissan would pay $3 billion for a 20 percent stake in G.M.
articles.abstract: Under a proposal by the billionaire Kirk Kerkorian, Renault and Nissan would pay $3 billion for a 20 percent stake in G.M.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 30 — General Motors' largest shareholder is pressing the troubled American auto giant to speed up its turnaround effort by forming an alliance with two foreign car companies, Nissan and Renault, which would pay $3 billion for a 20 percent stake in G.M.

articles.headline: Yearning to Put Papers Back in Local Hands
articles.snippet: Increasingly, investors want their hometown dailies free of absentee corporate owners.
articles.abstract: Increasingly, investors want their hometown dailies free of absentee corporate owners.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 30 — If the real estate billionaire Eli Broad had his way, The Los Angeles Times would run more photographs of donors at charity events. There would be fewer stories on movies and more about the city's museums and classical arts. And it would champion civic projects, becoming, in his view, the glue to unite a diverse and fractured city.

articles.headline: G.M. Is Pressed to Form Alliance With Two Rivals
articles.snippet: Kirk Kerkorian, General Motors' largest shareholder, is pressing company to speed up its turnaround effort by forming alliance with Nissan and Renault, which would pay $3 billion for 20 percent stake in GM; alliance would offer Kerkorian opportuni...
articles.abstract: Kirk Kerkorian, General Motors' largest shareholder, is pressing company to speed up its turnaround effort by forming alliance with Nissan and Renault, which would pay $3 billion for 20 percent stake in GM; alliance would offer Kerkorian opportunity to enlist help of Carlos Ghosn, hard-charging executive who oversees Nissan and Renault; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 30 - General Motors' largest shareholder is pressing the troubled American auto giant to speed up its turnaround effort by forming an alliance with two foreign car companies, Nissan and Renault, which would pay $3 billion for a 20 percent stake in G.M.

articles.headline: Airfares Made Easy (or Easier)
articles.snippet: You squeeze into your seat in the airliner, buckle up and then, against your best judgment, you start asking your seat mates what they paid for their airfare.      That's what Oren Etzioni did on a flight in 2002 and he discovered that, of course,...
articles.abstract: You squeeze into your seat in the airliner, buckle up and then, against your best judgment, you start asking your seat mates what they paid for their airfare.      That's what Oren Etzioni did on a flight in 2002 and he discovered that, of course, others paid less for their tickets. Even worse, said Mr. Etzioni, a professor of computer science and engineering at the University of Washington, ''they bought later than I did.''
articles.lead_paragraph: You squeeze into your seat in the airliner, buckle up and then, against your best judgment, you start asking your seat mates what they paid for their airfare.

articles.headline: Generic Drugs: The Window Has Loopholes
articles.snippet: A WEEK ago yesterday, Zocor's United States patent protection expired. Zocor, of course, is Merck's big cholesterol-lowering drug, which last year generated $4.4 billion for the company. As Alex Berenson pointed out in The New York Times, that mak...
articles.abstract: A WEEK ago yesterday, Zocor's United States patent protection expired. Zocor, of course, is Merck's big cholesterol-lowering drug, which last year generated $4.4 billion for the company. As Alex Berenson pointed out in The New York Times, that makes Zocor ''the largest-selling drug yet to be opened to generic competition.''     Not long ago, a big pharmaceutical company like Merck would have rolled over and played dead once its ''branded'' drug lost patent protection. For the first six months after the patent's expiration, the company would probably have maintained its old monopoly price, while a single generic drug maker, which had gained the right to sell its version exclusively for 180 days, undercut it by, say, 20 percent. After the six months were up, and half a dozen generic companies started making their own versions of the drug, the price would ''fall off the cliff,'' in the words of the generic drug expert Tim Van Biesen of Bain & Company. At which point, the branded drug would fade into oblivion.
articles.lead_paragraph: A WEEK ago yesterday, Zocor's United States patent protection expired. Zocor, of course, is Merck's big cholesterol-lowering drug, which last year generated $4.4 billion for the company. As Alex Berenson pointed out in The New York Times, that makes Zocor "the largest-selling drug yet to be opened to generic competition."

articles.headline: Yearning to Put Papers Back in Local Hands
articles.snippet: If the real estate billionaire Eli Broad had his way, The Los Angeles Times would run more photographs of donors at charity events. There would be fewer stories on movies and more about the city's museums and classical arts. And it would champion ...
articles.abstract: If the real estate billionaire Eli Broad had his way, The Los Angeles Times would run more photographs of donors at charity events. There would be fewer stories on movies and more about the city's museums and classical arts. And it would champion civic projects, becoming, in his view, the glue to unite a diverse and fractured city.     Newspapers are the soul of a community and they should be locally owned, Mr. Broad said one recent afternoon on the 12th floor of an office tower here overlooking acres of million-dollar homes. And that is why he would like to see The Los Angeles Times, now owned by the Chicago-based Tribune Company, acquired by a group of local organizations, including his own $2 billion foundation.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES, June 30 - If the real estate billionaire Eli Broad had his way, The Los Angeles Times would run more photographs of donors at charity events. There would be fewer stories on movies and more about the city's museums and classical arts. And it would champion civic projects, becoming, in his view, the glue to unite a diverse and fractured city.

articles.headline: Big Holder Looks to Turnaround Artist to Transform G.M.
articles.snippet: Carlos Ghosn has never recoiled from big challenges, and the auto industry has none bigger than fixing General Motors.     As the head of Nissan Motors, Mr. Ghosn rapidly transformed an also-ran to one of the most profitable major automakers. Sinc...
articles.abstract: Carlos Ghosn has never recoiled from big challenges, and the auto industry has none bigger than fixing General Motors.     As the head of Nissan Motors, Mr. Ghosn rapidly transformed an also-ran to one of the most profitable major automakers. Since he added the title of chief executive of Nissan's lagging French partner, Renault, a year ago, he has taken steps to begin a similar turnaround there.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT, June 30 - Carlos Ghosn has never recoiled from big challenges, and the auto industry has none bigger than fixing General Motors.

articles.headline: G.I.'s Investigated in Slayings of 4 and Rape in Iraq
articles.snippet: US military is investigating accusations that soldiers raped Iraqi woman in her home and killed her and three family members, including child; alleged rape and killings took place March 12 in vicinity of Mahmudiya, insurgent stronghold near Baghda...
articles.abstract: US military is investigating accusations that soldiers raped Iraqi woman in her home and killed her and three family members, including child; alleged rape and killings took place March 12 in vicinity of Mahmudiya, insurgent stronghold near Baghdad; US officials say investigation involves five soldiers from 502nd Infantry Regiment; say one soldier has admitted his role and has been arrested, and others are confined to their base; two soldiers from unit were abducted in town of Yusufiya and killed by insurgents in early June; Russian government offers $10 million for information leading to killers of five embassy workers in Baghdad (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, June 30 - The American military is investigating accusations that soldiers raped an Iraqi woman in her home and killed her and three family members, including a child, American officials said Friday.

articles.headline: Congo Nears Historic Election, Praying for Peace
articles.snippet: Congo is preparing for its first national election since 1965; it will be most expensive election ever held in Africa, costing international donors over $400 million; millions of ballots must be distributed across country size of Western Europe bu...
articles.abstract: Congo is preparing for its first national election since 1965; it will be most expensive election ever held in Africa, costing international donors over $400 million; millions of ballots must be distributed across country size of Western Europe but with only 300 miles of paved roads; biggest challenge will be getting Congo's competing groups to recognize and respect results, and managing outsized expectations of population exhausted by world's deadliest conflict since World War II; Joseph Kabila, president of interim government and son of rebel leader who overthrew longtime dictator Mobutu Sese Seko, is considered to have best chance among 33 presidential candidates; map; photos (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: GOMA, Congo - The drawing the Rev. Israel Mulenda held in his hands was as succinct a précis as any of the nightmares this vast central African nation has lived for the past decade.

articles.headline: Two Views of Terror Suspects: Die-Hards or Dupes
articles.snippet: Seven men who were arrested in Miami, Fla, on terror charges were shown on undercover videotapes reciting oaths of loyalty to Al Qaeda, repeating words that FBI informant had given them to say; tapes, played at federal court hearing by prosecutors...
articles.abstract: Seven men who were arrested in Miami, Fla, on terror charges were shown on undercover videotapes reciting oaths of loyalty to Al Qaeda, repeating words that FBI informant had given them to say; tapes, played at federal court hearing by prosecutors, did not provide evidence that men had money or firepower to blow up Sears Tower in Chicago and federal buildings in five cities, as they are accused of conspiring to do, or that they had actual ties to Al Qaeda; prosecutor Jacqueline M Arango says group's leader, Narseal Batiste, asked undercover informant for rockets, semiautomatic rifles and $50,000; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI, June 30 - The seven men who were arrested here last week on terror charges were shown Friday on undercover videotapes solemnly reciting oaths of loyalty to Al Qaeda, repeating the words that an F.B.I. informant had given them to say.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and Eric Lichtblau

articles.headline: Car Bomb Kills More Than 60 in Iraq Market
articles.snippet: The bombing was the deadliest insurgent assault since the new Shiite-led government was installed in May.
articles.abstract: The bombing was the deadliest insurgent assault since the new Shiite-led government was installed in May.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 1 — A powerful suicide car bomb ripped through a bustling street market in a Shiite slum here on Saturday, killing at least 62 people and wounding nearly 120 in the deadliest insurgent assault since the new Shiite-led government was installed in May, police officials and witnesses said.

articles.headline: Israeli Airstrike Over Gaza Hits Premier's Office
articles.snippet: Israel stepped up its campaign to pressure the Palestinians for the release of an Israeli soldier, who was said to be in stable condition.
articles.abstract: Israel stepped up its campaign to pressure the Palestinians for the release of an Israeli soldier, who was said to be in stable condition.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA, Sunday, July 2  An Israeli aircraft fired missiles into the empty offices of the Palestinian prime minister in Gaza City early Sunday, the highest profile target yet in Israel's escalating campaign to pressure the Palestinians for the release of an Israeli soldier.

articles.snippet: The history of Racine, Wis., like that of the nation as a whole, is also the story of how a community comes to grips with globalization.
articles.abstract: The history of Racine, Wis., like that of the nation as a whole, is also the story of how a community comes to grips with globalization.

articles.headline: A Sweetener With a Bad Rap
articles.snippet: It spooks foodies, parents and nutritionists alike. But is high-fructose corn syrup really that bad?
articles.abstract: It spooks foodies, parents and nutritionists alike. But is high-fructose corn syrup really that bad?
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERY time Marie Cabrera goes shopping, she brings along her mental checklist of things to avoid. It includes products with artery-clogging trans fats, cholesterol-inducing saturated fats, MSG and the bogeyman du jour, high-fructose corn syrup. That last one, she says, is the hardest to avoid unless she happens to be shopping in the small natural-foods section of her supermarket.

articles.headline: Buffett Children Emerge as a Force in Charity
articles.snippet: With about $1 billion each, Warren E. Buffett's children have been propelled into the top ranks of philanthropy.
articles.abstract: With about $1 billion each, Warren E. Buffett's children have been propelled into the top ranks of philanthropy.
articles.lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ill., June 28 — The three middle-aged children of Warren E. Buffett watched along with the rest of the country last week as their father, the celebrated investor, told the world that he would pass the bulk of his $40 billion personal fortune to the charitable foundation of Bill Gates, a fellow billionaire, and his wife, Melinda.

articles.headline: The Best Part Comes in the Third Act
articles.snippet: Why employers shouldn't bring down the curtain on older workers.
articles.abstract: Why employers shouldn't bring down the curtain on older workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE women in my family, at least those on my mother's side, seem to live long and well. My grandmother Pearl's "third act" was one of worldwide travel and voracious learning. When she died, well into her 80's, she had just signed up for a two-year course on Chinese history. Her sister, Minnie, my great-aunt, was a bookkeeper until she was 80 and then became an actress, reveling in the limousines that took her to the sets of a variety of national television ads.

articles.headline: Hiring Federal Lobbyists, Towns Learn Money Talks
articles.snippet: Cities and towns across country are increasingly putting lobbyists on retainer to win federal financing; number of public entities hiring private firms to represent them in Washington has nearly doubled since 1998 from 763 to 1,421; lobbyists for ...
articles.abstract: Cities and towns across country are increasingly putting lobbyists on retainer to win federal financing; number of public entities hiring private firms to represent them in Washington has nearly doubled since 1998 from 763 to 1,421; lobbyists for local governments have boomed alongside growth in 'earmark' appropriations; some critics say new ubiquity of lobbyists paid with public money perverts basic democratic tenets; graphs; photo; chronology (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: TREASURE ISLAND, Fla. - Rebuffed on several requests for state and federal financing to help rebuild its crumbling bridge, this small resort town was all but resigned to raising the money by doubling the 50-cent bridge toll, increasing property taxes and issuing bonds.
articles.byline: By Jodi Rudoren and Aron Pilhofer

articles.headline: Israeli Airstrike Over Gaza Hits Premier's Office
articles.snippet: Israeli aircraft fires missiles into empty offices of Palestinian Prime Min Ismail Haniya in Gaza City as part of escalating campaign to pressure Palestinians for release of kidnapped Israeli soldier Cpl Gilad Shalit; no casualties are reported as...
articles.abstract: Israeli aircraft fires missiles into empty offices of Palestinian Prime Min Ismail Haniya in Gaza City as part of escalating campaign to pressure Palestinians for release of kidnapped Israeli soldier Cpl Gilad Shalit; no casualties are reported as result of nighttime strike; second airstrike against building used by Hamas-linked security force kills one Hamas member; Israel has sought to pressure Palestinian leaders with similar tactics in past; photo (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA, Sunday, July 2 - An Israeli aircraft fired missiles into the empty offices of the Palestinian prime minister in Gaza City early Sunday, the highest profile target yet in Israel's escalating campaign to pressure the Palestinians for the release of an Israeli soldier.

articles.headline: Roberts Is at Court's Helm, but He Isn't Yet in Control
articles.snippet: Chief Justice John G Roberts Jr's goal of getting Supreme Court to speak softly and unanimously seems distant aspiration as important cases fail to produce majority opinions and members of court occasionally voice their frustration with colleagues...
articles.abstract: Chief Justice John G Roberts Jr's goal of getting Supreme Court to speak softly and unanimously seems distant aspiration as important cases fail to produce majority opinions and members of court occasionally voice their frustration with colleagues; Roberts himself has been in dissent almost as often as he was in majority; Justice Anthony M Kennedy has frequently cast deciding vote in important cases; early period of unanimity in 2005-2006 term, during which cases were dispatched quickly with narrow opinions, reflected agreement not on underlying legal principles but on desirability of moving on without getting bogged down; photos; chart (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, July 1 - As the dust settled on a consequential Supreme Court term, the first in 11 years with a change in membership and the first in two decades with a new chief justice, one question that lingered was whether it was now the Roberts court, in fact as well as in name.

articles.headline: The Economy May Be Global, but Not Languages or Culture
articles.snippet: Language barriers and cultural chasms both large and small are more predominant as workplace becomes increasingly multicultural and global economy requires increased interaction with foreign-born bosses, subordinates and co-workers; foreign-born a...
articles.abstract: Language barriers and cultural chasms both large and small are more predominant as workplace becomes increasingly multicultural and global economy requires increased interaction with foreign-born bosses, subordinates and co-workers; foreign-born account for 46 percent of total gain in labor force since 2000; photo (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: Precision, skill and a tendency toward perfection are what earned the Swiss watchmaker Vincent Roberts a customer service job with the luxury jeweler Harry Winston in New York.

articles.headline: Buffett Children Emerge as a Force in Charity
articles.snippet: Financier Warren E Buffet's middle-aged children Howard, Susie and Peter are trying to figure out how to manage gift from their father valued at about $1 billion each that will go to their own charitable foundations; gift will propel younger Buffe...
articles.abstract: Financier Warren E Buffet's middle-aged children Howard, Susie and Peter are trying to figure out how to manage gift from their father valued at about $1 billion each that will go to their own charitable foundations; gift will propel younger Buffets' foundations, along with larger foundation named for their late mother Susan Thompson Buffett, into top ranks of philanthropy, though they will be dwarfed by $60 billion Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, to which Buffett will pass bulk of his $40 billion personal fortune; photos; graph (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: DECATUR, Ill., June 28 - The three middle-aged children of Warren E. Buffett watched along with the rest of the country last week as their father, the celebrated investor, told the world that he would pass the bulk of his $40 billion personal fortune to the charitable foundation of Bill Gates, a fellow billionaire, and his wife, Melinda.

articles.headline: On Lake Michigan, a Global Village
articles.snippet: Profile of Racine, Wis, and its metropolitan area, which has undergone major transformation since 1968 from blue-collar Democratic factory town to one willing to face, if somewhat apprehensively, globalization and technological change; political a...
articles.abstract: Profile of Racine, Wis, and its metropolitan area, which has undergone major transformation since 1968 from blue-collar Democratic factory town to one willing to face, if somewhat apprehensively, globalization and technological change; political and business leaders advise that best course in uncertain economy is pragmatic blend of self-reliance and community support; photos; map; graphs (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: RACINE, Wis. - GARY BECKER, this city's mayor, remembers handing out fliers at local factory gates as a 10-year-old campaigner in Hubert H. Humphrey's ill-fated presidential bid in 1968. Mr. Becker, 48, is still a Democrat, but the factories and the traditional blue-collar jobs that filled the streets of his childhood are mostly gone, replaced by condominiums, restaurants and shops along Lake Michigan as well as an increasing number of service-sector jobs.

articles.headline: The Best Part Comes in the Third Act
articles.snippet: Lisa Belkin Life's Work column on unsuccessful attempts by her mother and others over age 60 to re-enter job market; says employers do not recognize contributions and advantages elderly have to offer; notes Civic Ventures, policy research organiza...
articles.abstract: Lisa Belkin Life's Work column on unsuccessful attempts by her mother and others over age 60 to re-enter job market; says employers do not recognize contributions and advantages elderly have to offer; notes Civic Ventures, policy research organization that works to redefine aging, will award its first Purpose Prizes of $100,000 each to five winners over age 60 who are changing world for better; drawing (M)
articles.lead_paragraph: THE women in my family, at least those on my mother's side, seem to live long and well. My grandmother Pearl's "third act" was one of worldwide travel and voracious learning. When she died, well into her 80's, she had just signed up for a two-year course on Chinese history. Her sister, Minnie, my great-aunt, was a bookkeeper until she was 80 and then became an actress, reveling in the limousines that took her to the sets of a variety of national television ads.

articles.headline: A Sweetener With a Bad Rap
articles.snippet: Article explores myths and realities about nutritional value of high-fructose corn syrup, which has, over last 25 years, become hard-to-avoid staple of American diet; many scientists say there is little data to back up its demonization and links w...
articles.abstract: Article explores myths and realities about nutritional value of high-fructose corn syrup, which has, over last 25 years, become hard-to-avoid staple of American diet; many scientists say there is little data to back up its demonization and links with obesity are based upon misperceptions and unproved theories; photos; diagrams (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: EVERY time Marie Cabrera goes shopping, she brings along her mental checklist of things to avoid. It includes products with artery-clogging trans fats, cholesterol-inducing saturated fats, MSG and the bogeyman du jour, high-fructose corn syrup. That last one, she says, is the hardest to avoid unless she happens to be shopping in the small natural-foods section of her supermarket.

articles.headline: Car Bomb Kills More Than 60 in Iraq Market
articles.snippet: Suicide car bomb in bustling market in Shiite Sadr City slum in Baghdad kills at least 62 people and wounds about 120 others; bombing occurs as Sunni Arab member of new Parliament Tayseer Najah al-Mashhadani and eight of her bodyguards are abducte...
articles.abstract: Suicide car bomb in bustling market in Shiite Sadr City slum in Baghdad kills at least 62 people and wounds about 120 others; bombing occurs as Sunni Arab member of new Parliament Tayseer Najah al-Mashhadani and eight of her bodyguards are abducted by militiamen; bombing and kidnapping pose most direct challenges yet to new Iraqi government, which has deployed tens of thousands of police officers and troops in recent weeks to try to secure capital; photos (L)
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD, Iraq, July 1 - A powerful suicide car bomb ripped through a bustling street market in a Shiite slum here on Saturday, killing at least 62 people and wounding nearly 120 in the deadliest insurgent assault since the new Shiite-led government was installed in May, police officials and witnesses said.

articles.headline: Israel Steps Up Raids in Bid to Free Soldier
articles.snippet: Israel intensified its attacks on Palestinian targets in Gaza, including the offices of Fatah, but also allowed in a limited supply of fuel and food.
articles.abstract: Israel intensified its attacks on Palestinian targets in Gaza, including the offices of Fatah, but also allowed in a limited supply of fuel and food.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA, Monday, July 3 — Israeli aircraft intensified their attacks on Palestinian targets in Gaza early on Monday, hitting the downtown offices of the Fatah political party here and sites in the northern part of the territory, a day after Israel's prime minister ordered his military to do whatever was necessary to pressure militants to free an Israeli soldier captured a week ago.
articles.byline: By Ian Fisher and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: Online Calling Heralds an Era of Lower Costs
articles.snippet: New competitors, including cable companies and start-ups like Vonage, are putting intense pressure on traditional phone companies.
articles.abstract: New competitors, including cable companies and start-ups like Vonage, are putting intense pressure on traditional phone companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Competition in the phone business, intensifying this year as Internet-based calling has taken root, has reached the point where many industry experts are anticipating an era of remarkably cheap and even free calls.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Ken Belson

articles.headline: Electoral Crisis in Mexico as Top 2 Declare Victory
articles.snippet: Minutes after election officials said they could not immediately determine a winner, both front-runners declared victory.
articles.abstract: Minutes after election officials said they could not immediately determine a winner, both front-runners declared victory.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY, July 2 — Election officials declared Sunday that they could not immediately determine a winner in the tightest presidential race in the country's history. Minutes later, the two front runners each declared victory, setting in motion an electoral crisis.

articles.headline: In Canada, the Torch Is Passed on a Quiet but Profitable Legacy
articles.snippet: The Thomson Corporation, based in Toronto, may be the biggest media company most people have never heard of.
articles.abstract: The Thomson Corporation, based in Toronto, may be the biggest media company most people have never heard of.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO, July 2 — The Thomson Corporation may be the biggest media company most people have never heard of.

articles.headline: Online Calling Heralds an Era of Lower Costs
articles.snippet: Competition in the phone business, intensifying this year as Internet-based calling has taken root, has reached the point where many industry experts are anticipating an era of remarkably cheap and even free calls.      That era would be built on ...
articles.abstract: Competition in the phone business, intensifying this year as Internet-based calling has taken root, has reached the point where many industry experts are anticipating an era of remarkably cheap and even free calls.      That era would be built on a vast migration of phone service from traditional networks to the Internet, where the calls become just another way to use Internet connections that consumers are paying for anyway.
articles.lead_paragraph: Competition in the phone business, intensifying this year as Internet-based calling has taken root, has reached the point where many industry experts are anticipating an era of remarkably cheap and even free calls.
articles.byline: By Matt Richtel and Ken Belson

articles.headline: In Canada, the Torch Is Passed on a Quiet but Profitable Legacy
articles.snippet: The Thomson Corporation may be the biggest media company most people have never heard of.      Those with long memories may recall it as the owner of The Times of London and a string of newspapers in small-town America. But Thomson, based in Toron...
articles.abstract: The Thomson Corporation may be the biggest media company most people have never heard of.      Those with long memories may recall it as the owner of The Times of London and a string of newspapers in small-town America. But Thomson, based in Toronto, sold those papers a long time ago and has turned itself into a major purveyor of media of a different sort -- specialized, high-end electronic information sold by subscription to lawyers, financial traders, academics and physicians.
articles.lead_paragraph: TORONTO, July 2 - The Thomson Corporation may be the biggest media company most people have never heard of.

articles.headline: Top Officials of Airbus and EADS Step Down
articles.snippet: The head of Airbus and the co-chief of its parent company resigned on Sunday after the disclosure of production delays for the Airbus A380 jumbo plane and an investigation into insider trading, which together have sent its shares tumbling.     Noë...
articles.abstract: The head of Airbus and the co-chief of its parent company resigned on Sunday after the disclosure of production delays for the Airbus A380 jumbo plane and an investigation into insider trading, which together have sent its shares tumbling.     Noël Forgeard, co-chief executive of the parent company, the European Aeronautic Defense and Space Company, and Gustav Humbert, the chief executive of Airbus, stepped down under pressure from their largest shareholders, the French government and the Lagardère Group of France on one side, and DaimlerChrysler of Germany on the other.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT, July 2 - The head of Airbus and the co-chief of its parent company resigned on Sunday after the disclosure of production delays for the Airbus A380 jumbo plane and an investigation into insider trading, which together have sent its shares tumbling.

articles.headline: Marijuana Fight Envelops Fisherman's Wharf
articles.snippet: The newest attraction planned for Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco's most popular tourist destination, has no sign, no advertisements and not even a scrap of sourdough. Yet everyone seems to think that the new business, the Green Cross, will be a ...
articles.abstract: The newest attraction planned for Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco's most popular tourist destination, has no sign, no advertisements and not even a scrap of sourdough. Yet everyone seems to think that the new business, the Green Cross, will be a hit, drawing customers from all over the region to sample its aromatic wares.      For some, that is exactly the problem.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: AT&T Is Calling to Ask About TV Service. Will Anyone Answer?
articles.snippet: Jesse Vallado looks like your average cable guy: tool belt around hips, golf shirt with company insignia and a van stuffed with gear.     But Mr. Vallado, who has been installing television services for two decades, now works for the phone company...
articles.abstract: Jesse Vallado looks like your average cable guy: tool belt around hips, golf shirt with company insignia and a van stuffed with gear.     But Mr. Vallado, who has been installing television services for two decades, now works for the phone company -- AT&T -- not the local cable provider. Hunched over a cable box outside a customer's suburban two-story home in a gated community here, he plugs in adapters and a bunch of wires that will turn on AT&T's new television service, U-verse.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO, June 27 - Jesse Vallado looks like your average cable guy: tool belt around hips, golf shirt with company insignia and a van stuffed with gear.

articles.headline: Israel Steps Up Raids in Bid to Free Soldier
articles.snippet: Israeli aircraft intensified their attacks on Palestinian targets in Gaza early on Monday, hitting the downtown offices of the Fatah political party here and sites in the northern part of the territory, a day after Israel's prime minister ordered ...
articles.abstract: Israeli aircraft intensified their attacks on Palestinian targets in Gaza early on Monday, hitting the downtown offices of the Fatah political party here and sites in the northern part of the territory, a day after Israel's prime minister ordered his military to do whatever was necessary to pressure militants to free an Israeli soldier captured a week ago.     Just after daybreak, Israeli tanks and troops began to move into northern Gaza from massed positions on the border.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA, Monday, July 3 - Israeli aircraft intensified their attacks on Palestinian targets in Gaza early on Monday, hitting the downtown offices of the Fatah political party here and sites in the northern part of the territory, a day after Israel's prime minister ordered his military to do whatever was necessary to pressure militants to free an Israeli soldier captured a week ago.
articles.byline: By Ian Fisher and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: A Blog Mogul Turns Bearish on Blogs
articles.snippet: THE blogging bubble has been taking on serious air of late. Last week, PaidContent.org, a blog that covers digital media, held its first mixer. It was, by all reports, filled to the brim with money and content guys speed dating on the way to marri...
articles.abstract: THE blogging bubble has been taking on serious air of late. Last week, PaidContent.org, a blog that covers digital media, held its first mixer. It was, by all reports, filled to the brim with money and content guys speed dating on the way to marriage.      Nick Denton, the founder of Gawker Media, was there, but he wasn't looking for love or money.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended

articles.headline: Electoral Crisis in Mexico as Top 2 Declare Victory
articles.snippet: Election officials declared Sunday that they could not immediately determine a winner in the tightest presidential race in the country's history. Minutes later, the two front runners each declared victory, setting in motion an electoral crisis.   ...
articles.abstract: Election officials declared Sunday that they could not immediately determine a winner in the tightest presidential race in the country's history. Minutes later, the two front runners each declared victory, setting in motion an electoral crisis.      The contest pitted Felipe Calderón, a conservative former energy minister backed by business leaders, against Andrés Manuel López Obrador, the firebrand leftist former mayor of Mexico City, supported mostly by the poor.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY, July 2 - Election officials declared Sunday that they could not immediately determine a winner in the tightest presidential race in the country's history. Minutes later, the two front runners each declared victory, setting in motion an electoral crisis.

articles.headline: A Search Engine That's Becoming an Inventor
articles.snippet: When Google was a graduate-school project being run from a Silicon Valley garage, its founders, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, built their own computers out of cheap parts meant for personal computers. They wanted to save money, and they felt that th...
articles.abstract: When Google was a graduate-school project being run from a Silicon Valley garage, its founders, Larry Page and Sergey Brin, built their own computers out of cheap parts meant for personal computers. They wanted to save money, and they felt that they could design a network of computers that would search the Web more efficiently than those available from traditional manufacturers.     Google no longer needs to pinch pennies. It is a solid member of the Fortune 500 with $9 billion in cash. Still, it is stubbornly sticking to its do-it-yourself approach to technology. Even as it spends more than $1.5 billion this year on operations centers and technology, most of the hundreds of thousands of servers it will deploy are being custom-made based on Google's own eccentric designs.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Saul Hansell and John Markoff

articles.headline: A New Partnership Binds Old Republican Rivals
articles.snippet: After years of competitive and often contentious dealings, President Bush and Senator John McCain of Arizona are building a deepening if impersonal relationship that is serving the political needs of both men.     Given their history of intense ri...
articles.abstract: After years of competitive and often contentious dealings, President Bush and Senator John McCain of Arizona are building a deepening if impersonal relationship that is serving the political needs of both men.     Given their history of intense rivalry and sometimes personally bitter combat, their newfound partnership is seen by some Republicans as born more of political calculation than personal evolution. Either way, it could prove valuable to Mr. McCain in his efforts to win the Republican presidential nomination in 2008 by sending a signal to Mr. Bush's conservative base and fund-raising network that, at a minimum, the White House will not stand in the Arizonan's way.
articles.lead_paragraph: Correction Appended
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg and Adam Nagourney
